contentrichtext.text: {{Unreferenced|date=December 2009}} A '''reflux suppressant''' is any one of a number of [[Medication|drugs]] used to combat [[oesophageal reflux]]. Commonly, following ingestion a 'raft' of [[alginic acid]] is created, floating on the stomach contents by carbon dioxide released by the drug. This forms a mechanical barrier to further reflux. Some preparations also contain [[antacid]]s to protect the [[oesophagus]]. Reflux can also be coincidentally reduced by the [[:Category:Motility stimulants|motility stimulants]] and [[antidopaminergic]]s. {{DEFAULTSORT:Reflux Suppressant}} [[Category:Drugs acting on the gastrointestinal system and metabolism]]
